Discussion
Renal cell carcinoma, a notorious malignancy within the 
urinary system, accounts for 5% of newly diagnosed can -
cer cases [ 2]. However, in clinical practice, the absence 
of characteristic early-stage manifestations—particu -
larly in c

source: pmc\Machine learning model in multi-omics perspective demystifies the prognostic sig.pdf
text:
nancy within the 
urinary system, accounts for 5% of newly diagnosed can -
cer cases [ 2]. However, in clinical practice, the absence 
of characteristic early-stage manifestations—particu -
larly in clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC)—has been 
extensively documented [ 27]– [28]. The classical triad of 
hematuria, flank pain, and abdominal mass is observed in 
approximately 60% of patients, with most cases (≥ 60%) 
already progressing to pathological T3 stage or beyond at diagnosis, correlating with dismal prognosis [ 29]. This 
underscores the critical need for identifying reliable bio -
markers to facilitate early intervention strategies. Pro -
tein crotonylation, as a post-translational modification, 
has been demonstrated to play pivotal roles in various 
biological processes including cancer progression. Nev -
ertheless, the prognostic significance of crotonylation 
heterogeneity in ccRCC remains poorly characterized. 
This gap has been addressed by our investigation through 
the establishment of a robust crotonylation-related prog -
nostic model. Mechanistically, the molecular heterogene -
ity of crotonylation during ccRCC progression has been 
partially elucidated, provi

source: pmc\Machine learning model in multi-omics perspective demystifies the prognostic sig.pdf
text:
the establishment of a robust crotonylation-related prog -
nostic model. Mechanistically, the molecular heterogene -
ity of crotonylation during ccRCC progression has been 
partially elucidated, providing valuable insights for opti -
mizing clinical management of this malignancy.
In the present study, dysregulated expression of 16 out 
of 18 crotonylation-related genes was observed in ccRCC, 
with ssGSEA-derived crotonylation scores being signifi -
cantly upregulated in tumor specimens, suggesting the 
potential critical role of crotonylation heterogeneity in 
ccRCC progression. Through WGCNA, a crotonylation-
associated gene module was identified for subsequent 
investigation. Functional annotation of this module was 
performed through comprehensive enrichment analyses.
Consistent enrichment patterns across GO, Dis -
GeNET, and WikiPathways databases highlighted the 
module’s involvement in angiogenesis. Angiogenesis, a 
well-documented malignant process in cancer progres -
sion, has been recognized to facilitate tumor metastasis 
and nourish tumor microenvironment development [ 30]. 
However, the immature vascular networks frequently 
observed in tumors are characterized by funct

source: pmc\Machine learning model in multi-omics perspective demystifies the prognostic sig.pdf
text:
been recognized to facilitate tumor metastasis 
and nourish tumor microenvironment development [ 30]. 
However, the immature vascular networks frequently 
observed in tumors are characterized by functional 
Fig. 13  Validation of differential expression of model genes. A Differential expression of model genes in TCGA-KIRC cohort B Differential expression of 
model genes in GSE40435 cohort C qRT-PCR validation of model gene expression in cell lines 

Page 18 of 22
Dai et al. BMC Urology           (2025) 25:229 
deficiencies that exacerbate hypoxia, thereby promoting 
tumor progression and chemoresistance [ 31]– [32].
Secondly, we observed that module genes were sig -
nificantly enriched in processes related to receptors, ion 
channels, and signaling pathways, particularly G protein-
coupled receptors (GPCRs). GPCR dysregulation has 
been reported to influence cancer progression through 
stimulation of proliferation-related signaling pathways 
and modulation of cytoskeletal reorganization, which 
enhances cellular adhesion and motility [ 33]. Intriguingly, 
KEGG pathway analysis revealed significant enrichment 
in calcium signaling and Ras signaling pathways. Cal -
cium ions, serving

source: pmc\Machine learning model in multi-omics perspective demystifies the prognostic sig.pdf
text:
n, which 
enhances cellular adhesion and motility [ 33]. Intriguingly, 
KEGG pathway analysis revealed significant enrichment 
in calcium signaling and Ras signaling pathways. Cal -
cium ions, serving as crucial secondary messengers, have 
been demonstrated to regulate critical cellular processes 
including cell cycle progression and apoptosis [ 34]. Dys -
regulation of intracellular calcium homeostasis has been 
associated with malignant phenotypes such as epithelial-
mesenchymal transition and angiogenesis [ 35]– [ 36]. 
Considering the therapeutic potential of calcium chan -
nel-targeting agents in various malignancies [ 36], the 
identified association between crotonylation heterogene -
ity and calcium signaling warrants further exploration. 
The RAS gene family (HRAS, NRAS, KRAS) [ 37], a clas -
sical oncogenic driver, has been implicated in promoting 
tumor proliferation and metastasis [ 38].
In addition, we found that module genes are also 
closely related to metabolic pathways. Beyond its role 
in carcinogenesis, the Ras signaling pathway has been 
shown to regulate glucose metabolism [ 39] and pro -
mote M2 macrophage polarization, thereby establishing 
an immunosuppressiv

source: pmc\Machine learning model in multi-omics perspective demystifies the prognostic sig.pdf
text:
Beyond its role 
in carcinogenesis, the Ras signaling pathway has been 
shown to regulate glucose metabolism [ 39] and pro -
mote M2 macrophage polarization, thereby establishing 
an immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment [ 40]. 
Moreover, we found a notable negative correlation with 
peroxisome-related processes ( r=−0.515). Peroxisomes, 
primarily responsible for reactive oxygen species (ROS) 
detoxification [ 41], were inversely associated with cro -
tonylation scores. This finding aligns with the dual role 
of ROS as secondary messengers that paradoxically pro -
mote tumorigenic processes including proliferation and 
angiogenesis [ 42]. The negative correlation suggests cro -
tonylation may counteract peroxisome-mediated tumor 
suppression.In conclusion, crotonylation-associated pro -
cesses were demonstrated to interact with multiple onco -
genic pathways, highlighting their significance in ccRCC 
pathogenesis.
Finally, it is worth emphasizing that the crotonylation-
related gene module is closely associated with cancer 
stemness. Significant correlations were demonstrated 
between crotonylation scores and Wnt/β-catenin sig -
naling ( r = 0.597). Activation of the Wnt/β-cat

source: pmc\Machine learning model in multi-omics perspective demystifies the prognostic sig.pdf
text:
ne module is closely associated with cancer 
stemness. Significant correlations were demonstrated 
between crotonylation scores and Wnt/β-catenin sig -
naling ( r = 0.597). Activation of the Wnt/β-catenin path -
way in malignancies has been associated with enhanced 
cancer stemness [ 43], promotion of metastatic pheno -
types [ 44], and crosstalk with Hedgehog/Notch pathways 
[45] - all critical regulators of cancer stem cell dynamics 
[46]. The observed positive correlation with Hedgehog signaling and Notch pathway enrichment further sup -
ports crotonylation’s potential regulatory role in these 
stemness-related pathways. Key regulatory roles were 
identified in angiogenesis, calcium/Ras signaling, redox 
homeostasis and stemness pathways, providing mecha -
nistic insights for future therapeutic exploration.
A robust prognostic stratification model was con -
structed using RSF combined with the plsRcox machine 
learning algorithm based on dysregulated crotonylation-
related genes. Five genes were incorporated: CDH13, 
PDGFD, PLCL1, DNASE1L3, and CD248. CDH13, a 
member of the cadherin family, is functionally implicated 
in cellular structure maintenance and growth regulation 
[47

source: pmc\Machine learning model in multi-omics perspective demystifies the prognostic sig.pdf
text:
ve genes were incorporated: CDH13, 
PDGFD, PLCL1, DNASE1L3, and CD248. CDH13, a 
member of the cadherin family, is functionally implicated 
in cellular structure maintenance and growth regulation 
[47]. Prior studies have emphasized that CDH13-medi -
ated metastasis is achieved through tumor angiogen -
esis promotion [ 48], which has been validated in ccRCC 
[49]. Furthermore, CDH13 was found to orchestrate the 
immune microenvironment in ccRCC and was negatively 
correlated with CD8 + T cell infiltration [ 50], a finding 
corroborated by our analyses.Platelet-derived growth 
factor D (PDGF-D) has been implicated in mesangial 
hyperplasia of the kidney and is considered a potential 
therapeutic target for renal fibrosis [ 51]. In renal carci -
noma, PDGFD overexpression has been shown to induce 
angiopoietin-1 upregulation, thereby promoting angio -
genesis and enhancing vascular pericyte coverage in 
tumor tissues [ 52]. The role of PLCL1 in cancer remains 
poorly characterized. In renal carcinoma, PLCL1 has 
been reported to initiate autophagic responses via the 
AMPK/mTOR pathway, ultimately leading to cancer cell 
death [ 53], and may serve as a component of telomere-
related p

source: pmc\Machine learning model in multi-omics perspective demystifies the prognostic sig.pdf
text:
nal carcinoma, PLCL1 has 
been reported to initiate autophagic responses via the 
AMPK/mTOR pathway, ultimately leading to cancer cell 
death [ 53], and may serve as a component of telomere-
related prognostic models to guide pharmacotherapy 
[54]. DNASE1L3, a member of the DNA degradation 
enzyme family, has been associated with favorable prog -
noses across multiple cancers. Specifically, in renal carci -
noma, DNASE1L3 was hypothesized to suppress cancer 
cell proliferation and migration through inactivation 
of the PI3K/AKT pathway [ 55]. In hepatocellular car -
cinoma, DNASE1L3 has been demonstrated to induce 
PANoptosis, enhancing tumoricidal activity within the 
microenvironment [ 56], while stress responses and 
tumor angiogenesis suppression were achieved through 
impairment of senescence-associated secretory pheno -
types [ 57]. Additionally, DNASE1L3-mediated CD8 + T 
cell functional stimulation has been identified as a criti -
cal mechanism in antitumor immunity in colorectal 
cancer [ 58]. In our study, sub-spot mapping of spatial 
transcriptomics revealed CD248 enrichment in fibro -
blasts. Intriguingly, CD248 + fibroblast infiltration was 
shown to mediate cell-extra

source: pmc\Machine learning model in multi-omics perspective demystifies the prognostic sig.pdf
text:
al 
cancer [ 58]. In our study, sub-spot mapping of spatial 
transcriptomics revealed CD248 enrichment in fibro -
blasts. Intriguingly, CD248 + fibroblast infiltration was 
shown to mediate cell-extracellular matrix interactions 
in the ccRCC microenvironment, facilitating tumor pro -
gression and shaping an immunosuppressive niche [ 59]. 
Notably, the ccRCC single-cell transcriptomic dataset 
(GSE159115) demonstrated pericyte-specific CD248

Dai et al. BMC Urology           (2025) 25:229 
upregulation. Previous studies in lung cancer indicated 
that CD248 potentiates angiogenesis by activating Wnt 
signaling in pericytes [ 60], a mechanism potentially con -
served in ccRCC. Further experimental validation will be 
conducted to elucidate the precise role of CD248 in this 
context.
Enrichment analysis of DEGs between high- and low-
risk subgroups was performed to delineate pathways 
driving ccRCC progression. Notably, KEGG enrichment 
highlighted the activation of neuroactive ligand-recep -
tor interactions, which had also been enriched in the 
previously identified crotonylation-related gene mod -
ule. Recent studies have demonstrated that neural ele -
ments may act

source: pmc\Machine learning model in multi-omics perspective demystifies the prognostic sig.pdf
text:
tive ligand-recep -
tor interactions, which had also been enriched in the 
previously identified crotonylation-related gene mod -
ule. Recent studies have demonstrated that neural ele -
ments may act as cancer facilitators by infiltrating the 
tumor microenvironment, where cancer cell proliferation 
and dissemination are stimulated through mechanisms 
involving nerve-derived growth factors or neurotrans -
mitters such as catecholamines [ 61]. Furthermore, neu -
ral infiltration, particularly of parasympathetic nerves, 
has been implicated in the induction of Wnt signaling 
to enhance cancer stemness, as documented in prior 
research [ 62].In the GO enrichment analysis, biologi -
cal processes related to lipid transport were prominently 
identified. Given that ccRCC progression is strongly 
associated with lipid dysregulation, coupled with the fre -
quent observation of lipid accumulation in cancer cells, 
it was hypothesized that aberrant lipid transport may 
play a role in disease advancement [ 63]. Additionally, the 
enrichment of organic anion transport processes war -
rants attention. Multiple reviews have emphasized that 
organic anion transporting polypeptides (OATPs), which

source: pmc\Machine learning model in multi-omics perspective demystifies the prognostic sig.pdf
text:
ancement [ 63]. Additionally, the 
enrichment of organic anion transport processes war -
rants attention. Multiple reviews have emphasized that 
organic anion transporting polypeptides (OATPs), which 
are frequently overexpressed in solid tumors, exhibit 
potential pro-tumorigenic effects. Their involvement 
in the transmembrane transport of chemotherapeutic 
agents further supports their investigation as therapeutic 
targets [ 64]– [65].
A comprehensive dissection of the immune micro -
environment was conducted to elucidate novel mecha -
nisms underlying ccRCC progression. Intriguingly, it 
was observed that Tregs were enriched in the high-risk 
subgroup, whereas M1 macrophage infiltration was pre -
dominantly identified in the low-risk subgroup. Previous 
studies have underscored that ccRCC is characterized 
by paradoxically intense immune infiltration coupled 
with profound exhaustion, a phenomenon mechanisti -
cally attributed to Treg-mediated immunosuppression 
[66]. Tregs, which are well-documented for orchestrat -
ing potent immune suppression [ 67], have been recog -
nized as a positive indicator of tumor progression when 
abundantly infiltrated [ 68].In the tumor immune mi

source: pmc\Machine learning model in multi-omics perspective demystifies the prognostic sig.pdf
text:
are well-documented for orchestrat -
ing potent immune suppression [ 67], have been recog -
nized as a positive indicator of tumor progression when 
abundantly infiltrated [ 68].In the tumor immune micro -
environment, M1 macrophages are established as pivotal 
antitumor effectors, with tumor growth inhibition being 
mediated through synergistic interactions with T cells 
and interferon signaling [ 69]– [70].Additionally, downregulation of multiple HLA mol -
ecules, particularly HLA class I, was detected in the 
high-risk subgroup. Reduced HLA class I expression 
has been mechanistically linked to unfavorable progno -
sis and disease progression in ccRCC [ 71], while patients 
with upregulated HLA-I expression have exhibited pro -
longed recurrence-free survival [ 72], collectively suggest -
ing that HLA-I serves as a clinically significant biomarker 
in ccRCC. These findings provide mechanistic insights 
into the marked prognostic disparities between risk 
subgroups.
To advance the clinical translatability of the model, an 
analysis of chemotherapeutic drug sensitivity was per -
formed between high- and low-risk subgroups. Notably, 
heightened sensitivity to 5-fluorouracil and cis

source: pmc\Machine learning model in multi-omics perspective demystifies the prognostic sig.pdf
text:
inical translatability of the model, an 
analysis of chemotherapeutic drug sensitivity was per -
formed between high- and low-risk subgroups. Notably, 
heightened sensitivity to 5-fluorouracil and cisplatin was 
observed in high-risk patients, whereas low-risk patients 
exhibited preferential responsiveness to gefitinib and 
cyclophosphamide. Based on these findings, patients 
can be stratified at treatment initiation using the model’s 
biomarkers, enabling risk subgroup-tailored therapeu -
tic strategies. Further optimization of clinical outcomes 
may be achieved through periodic reassessment of risk 
status during treatment, with therapeutic regimens being 
dynamically adjusted in accordance with updated stratifi -
cation results. This adaptive approach ensures precision 
in treatment delivery and maximizes prognostic benefits.
In the single-cell and spatial transcriptomics analysis 
section, our goal is to explore the expression patterns 
of model genes, thereby laying the foundation for sub -
sequent in-depth analysis. Single-cell and spatial tran -
scriptomics maps complement each other, and we have 
achieved this by integrating the C2 sample from the Spa -
tialTME database an

source: pmc\Machine learning model in multi-omics perspective demystifies the prognostic sig.pdf
text:
n for sub -
sequent in-depth analysis. Single-cell and spatial tran -
scriptomics maps complement each other, and we have 
achieved this by integrating the C2 sample from the Spa -
tialTME database and the GSE159115 sample from the 
TISCH2 portal. However, we must clearly recognize that 
research conclusions drawn from local samples (even 
highly characterized public samples) have inherent limi -
tations in terms of their generalizability when applied to 
broader, more heterogeneous human cohorts. The first 
limitation pertains to individual variability. Human pop -
ulations exhibit significant differences in genetic back -
ground, epigenetic status, environmental exposure, and 
lifestyle. A single sample cannot capture this biological 
heterogeneity. Therefore, the expression patterns of Cro -
tonylation-related key genes observed in this study may 
not be directly extrapolated to all individuals. In larger 
cohorts, specific findings may only be present in spe -
cific subgroups or exhibit different intensities or patterns 
in other individuals. Second, we must emphasize the 
uncertainty of population specificity. The samples ana -
lyzed in this study were sourced from Europe and

source: pmc\Machine learning model in multi-omics perspective demystifies the prognostic sig.pdf
text:
hibit different intensities or patterns 
in other individuals. Second, we must emphasize the 
uncertainty of population specificity. The samples ana -
lyzed in this study were sourced from Europe and North 
America, and their applicability and effect sizes may 
vary significantly when applied to other racial or ethnic 
groups (e.g., African American, Asian American, Latino, 
etc.). Population structure is a key factor influencing the 

Page 20 of 22
Dai et al. BMC Urology           (2025) 25:229 
generalizability of biomedical research results. Addition -
ally, we must acknowledge the amplification of technical 
biases and batch effects. While individual samples help 
control for technical variability inherent in the method 
itself, in larger cohort studies, technical factors such as 
sample collection, processing, storage, and batch effects 
introduce significantly increased variability. The perfor -
mance observed under ideal conditions in this study may 
be affected by these confounding factors in actual large-
scale applications. In summary, the use of spatial tran -
scriptomics data from SpatialTME and the GSE159115 
dataset from the TISCH2 portal provided this study with 
an

source: pmc\Machine learning model in multi-omics perspective demystifies the prognostic sig.pdf
text:
ding factors in actual large-
scale applications. In summary, the use of spatial tran -
scriptomics data from SpatialTME and the GSE159115 
dataset from the TISCH2 portal provided this study with 
an unparalleled and efficient means of exploring gene 
expression patterns. However, the results of this study 
should be regarded as important preliminary findings 
obtained under controlled conditions. To fully under -
stand their biological significance and clinical trans -
lational potential, and to assess their true universality, 
future studies must be expanded to include large-scale, 
diverse human cohorts encompassing different races, 
genders, ages, and disease states (if applicable). Future 
work will focus on such validation and generalization, 
while also delving into the modifying effects of interindi -
vidual differences on the study findings, which will be the 
core direction of our next phase of research.
While the findings of this study are promising, several 
limitations must be acknowledged. First, patient data 
were primarily obtained from public datasets, which 
may introduce population selection bias due to under -
representation of ethnic diversity. To address this,

source: pmc\Machine learning model in multi-omics perspective demystifies the prognostic sig.pdf
text:
t be acknowledged. First, patient data 
were primarily obtained from public datasets, which 
may introduce population selection bias due to under -
representation of ethnic diversity. To address this, future 
studies will involve the acquisition of larger, multieth -
nic cohorts to enhance the generalizability and validity 
of the model. Furthermore, prospective clinical cohorts 
focused on treatment responses are planned to evalu -
ate therapeutic benefit disparities across risk subgroups. 
Additionally, the current analysis relied predominantly 
on bioinformatic approaches, leaving the precise mech -
anisms through which crotonylation-related genes 
regulate ccRCC progression incompletely elucidated. 
Collaborative efforts with specialized laboratories will 
therefore be prioritized to conduct in-depth molecular 
and cellular experiments, including functional valida -
tion of crotonylation heterogeneity in ccRCC pathogen -
esis. These investigations aim to delineate the biological 
underpinnings of crotonylation-mediated tumor progres -
sion and identify novel therapeutic targets.

Original Article
The miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster promotes
postoperative progression of early-stagenon-small cell lung cancer
Xiaoqing Fan,1,3Shaolin Tao,1,3Qing Li,2Bo Deng,1Qun-You Tan,1and Hua Jin1
1Department of Thoracic Surgery, Daping Hospital, Army Medical University, Chongqing 400042, China;2Cancer Center, Daping Hospital, Army Medical University,
Chongqing 400042, China
Even with optimal surgery, many early-stage non-small cell
lung cancer (NSCLC) patients die of recurrence. Unfortunately,
there are no precise predictors for postoperative recurrence in
early-stage NSCLC, and the recurrence mechanism is still un-clear. In this study, we found that simultaneous overexpressionof all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster was closely asso-ciated with postoperative recurrence, b-catenin upregulation
and promoter methylation of p16 and CDH13 in early-stageNSCLC patients. In addition, in vitro and in vivo experiments
show that overexpression or inhibition of all miRNAs in themiR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster signi ﬁcantly stimulated or inhibited
NSCLC cell stemness, tumorigenicity and metastasis. Further-more, we demonstrated that the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster miR-
NAs activated Wnt/ b-catenin

source: pmc\The miR-23a_27a_24-2 cluster promotes postoperative progression of early-stage n.pdf
text:
24-2 cluster signi ﬁcantly stimulated or inhibited
NSCLC cell stemness, tumorigenicity and metastasis. Further-more, we demonstrated that the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster miR-
NAs activated Wnt/ b-catenin signaling by targeting their sup-
pressors and stimulated promoter methylation-inducedsilencing of p16 and CDH13 by affecting DNA methylation-related genes expression. Our ﬁndings suggest that simulta-
neous high expression of all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster represents a new biomarker for predicting postop-erative recurrence in early-stage NSCLC. The miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster miRNAs stimulate early-stage NSCLC progressionthrough simultaneously stimulating Wnt/ b-catenin signaling,
and promoter methylation-induced tumor suppressor genessilencing. In addition, simultaneous inhibition of all miRNAs
in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster may be a useful strategy for
treatment of early-stage NSCLC recurrence.
INTRODUCTION
Lung cancer remains the leading cause of cancer incidence and mor-
tality worldwide.1Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is the main
subtype of lung cancer and accounts for 75% –80% of all cases, and
approximately 30% of NSCLC patients are diagnosed with early-stageNSCL

source: pmc\The miR-23a_27a_24-2 cluster promotes postoperative progression of early-stage n.pdf
text:
lity worldwide.1Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is the main
subtype of lung cancer and accounts for 75% –80% of all cases, and
approximately 30% of NSCLC patients are diagnosed with early-stageNSCLC (stage I and II).
2Surgery is the standard treatment for early-
stage NSCLC; however, 15% of stage I and 40% of stage II NSCLC pa-tients develop postoperative recurrence, which is the major cause oftreatment failure.
3Thus, identifying biomarkers for predicting recur-
rence after curative resection will be bene ﬁcial for patient care.
Unfortunately, biomarkers that can accurately predict postoperativerecurrence of early-stage NSCLC have not been identi ﬁed and the un-
derlying mechanisms of recurrence are still unclear.Recent studies have found that several factors are associated with the
postoperative progression of early-stage NSCLC, including high
expression of b-catenin.
4b-catenin is a central signal transducer
of Wnt/ b-catenin signaling, and hyperactivated Wnt/ b-catenin
signaling stimulates cancer stem cell (CSC) development.5,6Impor-
tantly, CSCs play a crucial role in promoting tumor recurrencebecause these cells present self-renewal, high invasiveness, hightumorigenicity,

source: pmc\The miR-23a_27a_24-2 cluster promotes postoperative progression of early-stage n.pdf
text:
stimulates cancer stem cell (CSC) development.5,6Impor-
tantly, CSCs play a crucial role in promoting tumor recurrencebecause these cells present self-renewal, high invasiveness, hightumorigenicity, and can differentiate into all tumor cell types.
7In
addition, studies have shown that aberrant methylation in the pro-moters of certain tumor suppressor genes (TSGs) and the abnormalpromoter methylation-induced downregulation of TSGs are associ-ated with postoperative progression of early-stage NSCLC, includingp16 and cadherin 13 (CDH13).
8–10Thus, investigating the deregula-
tion mechanism of Wnt/ b-catenin signaling and promoter methyl-
ation of TSGs are important for understanding the postoperativeprogression of early-stage NSCLC and promoting the future develop-ment of novel therapeutic strategies.
miRNAs are small noncoding RNAs that inhibit gene expression
through translational repression and mRNA degradation by bindingto the 3
0UTR of target genes.11Studies show that most types of cancer
present dysregulated miRNA expression and that aberrantly ex-pressed miRNAs are correlated with postoperative recurrence,
12
Wnt/ b-catenin signaling hyperactivation,6and abnormal methyl-
ation

text:
cancer
present dysregulated miRNA expression and that aberrantly ex-pressed miRNAs are correlated with postoperative recurrence,
12
Wnt/ b-catenin signaling hyperactivation,6and abnormal methyl-
ation-induced TSG downregulation in lung cancer.13These ﬁndings
suggest that miRNAs may represent potential biomarkers for predict-ing postoperative recurrence of NSCLC and could contribute torecurrence by activating Wnt/ b-catenin signaling and abnormal
methylation-induced TSG silencing.
In this study, we demonstrated that simultaneously upregulated
expression level of all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster is in-dependent predictor for postoperative recurrence and poor outcome

RESULTS
High expression of all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster is
associated with postoperative recurrence and poor prognosis in
early-stage NSCLC patients
To identify the miRNAs associated with postoperative recurrence of
early-stage NSCLC, we performed small RNA sequencing using pri-mary tumors from early-stage NSCLC patients who relapsed within40 months after surgery and patients who did not relapse within 5years after surgery, because 80% of early-stage NSCLC recurrencesoccur within 40 months after surgery.
14The miR-23a/27a/24-2 clus-
ter includes miR-23a, miR-27a, and miR-24-2,15and previous studies
have shown these miRNAs play an oncogenic role in gastric cancer16
and glioma through synergistic effects.17But there is no research re-
ported about miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster and NSC

previous studies
have shown these miRNAs play an oncogenic role in gastric cancer16
and glioma through synergistic effects.17But there is no research re-
ported about miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster and NSCLC recurrence. Our
mRNA sequencing results showed that miR-23a, miR-27a, and miR-24-2 are highly expressed in the primary tumors of the early-stage
NSCLC patients who had postoperative relapse and were in the top10 molecules with the greatest changes ( Figures 1 A–1C), suggesting
that these miRNAs may be involved in the postoperative progressionof early-stage NSCLC. To prove this hypothesis, based on the hybrid-ization scores of the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster miRNAs in primarytumors ( Figure 1 D), 105 postoperative early-stage NSCLC patients
(stage I –II) were divided into the following three groups: all miRNAs
with high expression, all miRNAs with low expression, and high
expression of one to two miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster.Then, the correlation between miRNA expression levels andpostoperative progression of early-stage NSCLC patients wasanalyzed. As shown in Figure 1 E, 77% of the patients in the all miRNA
high-expression group experienced postoperative recurrence, andthey a

high-expression group experienced postoperative recurrence, andthey accounted for 83% of the total relapsed cases. However, only14% of the patients in the one to two miRNA high-expression groupand 18% of the patients in the all miRNAs low expression groupexperienced postoperative recurrence ( Figure 1 E). Notably, patients
in the all miRNAs high expression group had a shorter median recur-
rence-free survival (RFS) time and a lower RFS rate than the patients

in the other two groups ( Figure 1 F). Similar results were observed in
the 5-year overall survival rate analysis ( Figure 1 G). In addition, our
multivariable analyses showed that simultaneous high expression of
all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster is an independent pre-dictor for postoperative recurrence and poor prognosis in early-stageNSCLC patients ( Table 1 ). Altogether, our ﬁndings indicate that high
expression level of all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster mayrepresent a biomarker for predicting postoperative recurrence andpoor prognosis in early-stage NSCLC. In addition, simultaneousoverexpression of all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cl

text:
a/24-2 cluster mayrepresent a biomarker for predicting postoperative recurrence andpoor prognosis in early-stage NSCLC. In addition, simultaneousoverexpression of all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster mayhave synergistic stimulatory effects on early-stage NSCLCprogression.
Overexpression of all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster
signiﬁcantly promoted NSCLC progression
To investigate whether miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster play
a synergistic role in NSCLC progression, we selected NSCLC cell lineswith high or low expression of all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2cluster ( Figure S1 A) and transfected them with inhibitor or mimics of
the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster miRNAs ( Figure S1 B), respectively.
Then, these cells were subjected to malignancy analysis. Our resultsshowed that overexpression or inhibition of all miRNAs in themiR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster more signi ﬁcantly promoted or suppressed
NSCLC cell sphere formation ( Figure 2 A), soft agar colony formation
(Figure 2 B), and cell invasion and migration than single miRNA ( Fig-
ures 2 C and 2D). These ﬁndings indicate that simultaneous overex-
pression of all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster has a syner-gistic eff

source: pmc\The miR-23a_27a_24-2 cluster promotes postoperative progression of early-stage n.pdf
text:
nd cell invasion and migration than single miRNA ( Fig-
ures 2 C and 2D). These ﬁndings indicate that simultaneous overex-
pression of all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster has a syner-gistic effect in promoting NSCLC cell stemness, tumorigenicity, andmetastasis. In addition, inhibition of all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster may be an effective strategy for inhibiting NSCLCprogression.
Furthermore, we con ﬁrm the effects of the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster
miRNAs on NSCLC progression in vivo . First, we generated NSCLC
cell lines that stably express high or low levels of the miR-23a/27a/
24-2 cluster miRNAs ( Figure S1 C). Then, using these cell lines wegenerated subcutaneous xenograft models. Our experiments showed
that NSCLC cells that overexpressed the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster
displayed higher tumorigenicity than the control ( Figure 3 A).
Notably, only NSCLC cells overexpressing the miR-23a/27a/24-2cluster formed visible tumors when 5 /C210
3cells were implanted ( Fig-
ure 3 A), and obviously upregulated expression levels of cancer stem-
ness markers, such as CD133 and ALDH1, compared with the control(Figure 3 B). In contrast, inhibition of the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster

source: pmc\The miR-23a_27a_24-2 cluster promotes postoperative progression of early-stage n.pdf
text:
3 A), and obviously upregulated expression levels of cancer stem-
ness markers, such as CD133 and ALDH1, compared with the control(Figure 3 B). In contrast, inhibition of the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster
(Figure S1 C) dramatically inhibited NSCLC cell tumorigenicity ( Fig-
ure 3 C). Then, we investigated the effects of the miR-23a/27a/24-2
cluster on NSCLC metastasis in vivo . As shown in Figure 3 D, tumor
nodule formation on the lung surface signi ﬁcantly increased or
decreased with overexpression or inhibition of the miR-23a/27a/
24-2 cluster compared with their control in tail vein injection lungmetastasis models. Similar results were further observed in orthotopicmodels ( Figure 3 E). These ﬁndings suggest that overexpression of the
miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster strongly stimulates NSCLC progressionin vivo and that inhibition of the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster is an effec-
tive strategy for the treatment of NSCLC.
Overexpression of all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster
signiﬁcantly downregulated suppressors of Wnt/ b-catenin
signaling and upregulated b-catenin in NSCLC
To investigate the oncogenic mechanism of the miR-23a/27a/24-2
cluster miRNAs in NSCLC, we performed mRNA sequencing

source: pmc\The miR-23a_27a_24-2 cluster promotes postoperative progression of early-stage n.pdf
text:
gulated suppressors of Wnt/ b-catenin
signaling and upregulated b-catenin in NSCLC
To investigate the oncogenic mechanism of the miR-23a/27a/24-2
cluster miRNAs in NSCLC, we performed mRNA sequencing usingNSCLC cells overexpressing all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2cluster and their control cells. The results showed that overexpres-sion of all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster increased themRNA expression levels of b-catenin (CTNNB1) and its down-
stream genes CD44 and c-Myc ( Figure 4 A). In addition, gene set
enrichment analysis results show that overexpression of the miR-
23a/27a/24-2 cluster miRNAs associated with activation of Wnt/
b-catenin signaling pathway in NSCLC cells ( Figure 4 B). Similar re-
sults were observed in immunohistochemistry (IHC) analysis of tu-mor tissues in a xenograft model ( Figure 4 C). Importantly, western
blot analysis showed that overexpression of all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster more signi ﬁcantly upregulated b-catenin,
CD44, and c-Myc than single miRNA overexpression ( Figure 4 D).
In contrast, inhibition of all miRNAs of the miR-23a/27a/24-2 clus-ter more signi ﬁcantly downregulated the expression of b-catenin,
CD44, and c-Myc than

source: pmc\The miR-23a_27a_24-2 cluster promotes postoperative progression of early-stage n.pdf
text:
han single miRNA overexpression ( Figure 4 D).
In contrast, inhibition of all miRNAs of the miR-23a/27a/24-2 clus-ter more signi ﬁcantly downregulated the expression of b-catenin,
CD44, and c-Myc than inhibition of the single miRNA ( Figure 4 D).
This synergistic effect on b-catenin expression was further
conﬁrmed by immuno ﬂuorescence (IF) in NSCLC cells ( Figure 4 E),
suggesting that overexpression of all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster signi ﬁcantly activates Wnt/ b-catenin signaling through
a synergistic effect in NSCLC.
Furthermore, mRNA sequencing results also showed that overexpres-
sion of all miNRAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster simultaneouslyinhibited multiple suppressors of the Wnt/ b-catenin signaling,
namely, nemo-like kinase (NLK), glycogen synthase kinase 3 b
(GSK3 b), and CTNNBIP1 ( Figure 4 A). Notably, overexpression of
all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster more signi ﬁcantly in-
hibited NLK, GSK3 b, and CTNNBIP1 expression than singleTable 1. Multivariable analyses of prognostic factors for overall and

Next, we investigated whether Wnt/ b-catenin signaling and DNA hy-
permethylation were directly involved in the oncogenic role of themiR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster. As shown in Figure 6 ,b-catenin silencing
or 5-azad treatment partly inhibited overexpression of the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster-induced stimulation of sphere formation ( Fig-
ure 6 A), soft agar colony formation ( Figure 6 B), and cell invasion
and migration ( Figure 6 C) in NSCLC cells. However, the combination
ofb-catenin silencing and 5-azad treatment more completely blocked
the overexpression of miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster-induced stimulation
of sphere formation ( Figure 6 A), soft agar colony formation ( Fig-
ure 6 B), and cell invasion and migration ( Figure 6 C) than single treat-
ments. In addition, IHC analysis of xenograft tumors showed thatinhibition of the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster inhibited b-catenin
expression but increased the expression of p16 and CDH13 ( Fig-ure 6 D).

DISCUSSION
We report for the ﬁrst time that simultaneous high expression of all
miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster is a powerful biomarker
for predicting postoperative recurrence and prognosis in early-stage
NSCLC. Previous studies have shown that upregulated expressionlevels of individual miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster are asso-ciated with the progression of various cancers.
20–23However, our
clinical data showed that all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 clusterare simultaneously upregulated in the primary tumors of early-stageNSCLC patients with postoperative recurrence, and that simulta-neous high expression of all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 clusteris more closely correlated with postoperative recurrence and poorprognosis in early-

source: pmc\The miR-23a_27a_24-2 cluster promotes postoperative progression of early-stage n.pdf
text:
with postoperative recurrence, and that simulta-neous high expression of all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 clusteris more closely correlated with postoperative recurrence and poorprognosis in early-stage NSCLC compared with high expression of in-dividual miRNAs ( Figure 1 ). 8However, the highlight of this study are our clinical data
showing that simultaneous high expression of all miRNAs in themiR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster is a more powerful biomarker for predict-ing postoperative recurrence in early-stage NSCLC than highb-catenin expression or p16 and CDH13 promoter methylation.
Our clinical data showed that postoperative relapsed patients in the
b-catenin high expression group and the p16 and CDH13 promoter
methylation groups accounted for 73% and 50% of the total relapsedcases ( Figures S3 A and S3D), respectively, whereas the number of
postoperative relapsed patients in the all miRNA high expressiongroup accounted for 83% of the total relapsed cases ( Figure 1 E). How-

6or promoter methyl-
ation of TSGs, including p16 and CDH13,8are important factorsthat promote NSCLC recurrence. In this study, clinical data

p16 and CDH13 promoters in early-stage NSCLC were closely
correlated with high expression of all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster ( Figure 7 ). In addition, a series of in vitro and
in vivo experiments showed that NSCLC progression promoted
by miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster miRNAs dependent on both Wnt/b-catenin signaling activatio n and DNA methylation-induced
TSG downregulation ( Figures 2 ,3,4,5,a n d 6), indicating that
the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster miRNAs play an oncogenic role bysimultaneously stimulating Wnt/ b-catenin signaling and methyl-
ation-induced TSG downregulation.

that targeting the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster may be a useful strategyfor the treatment or prevention of postoperative early-stage NSCLCrecurrence.
In summary, our study clearly indicates that simultaneous high
expression of all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster representsa new biomarker for predicting recurrence and poor prognosis inpostoperative early-stage NSCLC patients. Simultaneous Wnt/ b-cat-
enin signaling activation and DNA methylation-induced TSG down-regulation are important factors leading to postoperative recurrenceof early-stage NSCLC, which is closely related to overexpression ofall miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 cluster. In addition, simulta-neous inhibition of all miRNAs in the miR-23a/27a/24-2 clustermay be an effective novel strategy for the treatment of early-stage
NSCLC recurrence ( Figure 7 G).MATERIALS AND METHODS

Statistical analysis
Data are presented as mean ±standard deviation and differences were
considered statistically signi ﬁcant at a p value of less than 0.05. Statis-
tical differences between treatment groups were analyzed by one-way
analysis of variance and Duncan ’s multiple range test using SAS sta-
tistical software. The survival rate of NSCLC patients was calculatedusing Kaplan-Meier survival analysis.
